Russia and North Korea just signed a military assistance agreement, and unexpectedly, North Korea has already started deploying troops. According to media reports, under the authorization of North Korea's Supreme Leader Kim Jong-un, a total of 20,000 troops from four North Korean engineering brigades will soon arrive in the eastern Ukraine region. Their purpose is not to directly participate in the Russia-Ukraine war but to help Russia strengthen its military fortifications in the area. However, this move has met with strong opposition from the United States and South Korea, and Ukrainian President Zelensky is also in a state of panic. Although North Korea is not directly engaging in combat, its actions are tantamount to indirect involvement. After all, once North Korean engineers arrive, Russia can redeploy more troops from construction duties to the front lines against Ukraine.

This situation is certainly unbearable for Zelensky. The reason the U.S. and South Korea are so unsettled is clearly because they are worried that if North Korea faces trouble in the future, Russia is highly likely to step in and help. The formal activation of a military alliance would be bad news for the U.S. and South Korea. However, the most anxious person right now is Ukrainian President Zelensky. If he decides to make a last-ditch effort on the front lines, can he turn the tide? Media reports suggest that Zelensky has finally succumbed to pressure and sought help from China. Ukraine plans to launch a large-scale counteroffensive in the Zaporizhzhia and Donetsk regions in July. Although Ukraine has the resources of more than 20 NATO countries behind it, the outcomes of several confrontations have been unacceptable to Zelensky, as they have not only failed to gain an advantage but have also resulted in disadvantages.

Now that North Korea is also getting involved, it becomes even more unfavorable for Ukraine to reverse the situation. In this context, Zelensky has turned his attention to China, hoping that China can help resolve the crisis. It seems that Zelensky has forgotten his hostile attitude towards China at the Shangri-La Dialogue, where he openly criticized China for interfering with the "Swiss Peace Summit." Now that he is in trouble, he turns to China for help. In fact, at the "Swiss Peace Summit," which China did not attend, the world once again witnessed China's global influence. After China announced it would not participate in the summit, more than a dozen countries also declared they would not attend, including South Africa, India, and Brazil. These countries are either BRICS members or partners in China's "Belt and Road" initiative, clearly demonstrating China's influence.

On the other hand, Zelensky is also worried that if relations with China deteriorate, it might push China closer to Russia, which would be a significant loss. However, Zelensky's concerns are somewhat unnecessary. China has long made its stance clear: it remains neutral in the Russia-Ukraine conflict and does not take sides. China has consistently pushed for a political resolution to the conflict between Russia and Ukraine. It is Ukraine's unwavering alignment with the U.S. and the West that has prolonged this conflict. The urgent task for Ukraine is to correct its attitude, recognize the fact that Russia holds the advantage on the front lines, and quickly come to the negotiating table. With the support of neutral countries like China, a peace plan that serves the interests of both parties should be reached to avoid further casualties.

Finnish President Alexander Stubb stated that Russia's dependence on China has reached such a level that if the Chinese government wished, it could end the war in Ukraine.

In an interview in Helsinki on Tuesday, President Stubb said, "Russia is now very dependent on China." "A single phone call from President Xi Jinping could resolve this crisis."

Bloomberg reported that these remarks reflect the growing frustration among Ukraine's allies over China's perceived support for Russia's war efforts. They accuse Beijing of providing weapon technology and components to the Kremlin and helping Moscow circumvent international trade restrictions.

The 56-year-old new Finnish president said, "If he says, 'It's time to start peace negotiations,' Russia will be forced to do so." "They have no choice."

China rejected this suggestion

Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said at a regular press conference in Beijing on Wednesday, "China and Russia are both independent major countries. China did not create the Ukraine crisis." She also assured, "We will always stand on the side of peaceful dialogue, maintain communication with relevant parties, including Russia, and play a constructive role in the political resolution of the crisis."

Bloomberg's report stated that Xi Jinping has been trying to portray China as a neutral party in discussions about the Russia-Ukraine war. The Chinese government has also criticized Russia for attacking civilians and threatening to use nuclear weapons. However, China fundamentally opposes international sanctions, stating that it only respects sanctions supported by the United Nations, and accuses the United States and its allies of fueling the war by providing weapons to Ukraine.

Trade: China-Russia up, EU-Russia down

According to Bloomberg-compiled statistics, last year China accounted for about 28% of Russia's total trade, up from 19% in 2021. In contrast, the EU's share of Russia's trade fell from 36% to 17% over the same period.

On May 16, Xi Jinping hosted Russian President Vladimir Putin in Beijing and called for an international conference, including Russia and Ukraine, to address what he called the "Ukraine issue."

Xi Jinping and Putin attended the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit, which opened on Wednesday in Astana, the capital of Kazakhstan. They met there.

The new Finnish head of state was sworn in on March 1. In this country of 5.5 million people, he has served as Prime Minister, Finance Minister, and Foreign Minister. His predecessor, Sauli Niinisto, reached the constitutional term limit after 12 years in office.

Ending Russia's invasion of Ukraine is beneficial for China

Speaking in the gilded presidential palace, a former residence from when Finland was part of the Russian Empire, President Stubb said that ending Putin's "war of aggression and colonization" in Ukraine is beneficial for China. Because "China needs to uphold international rules regarding territorial integrity and sovereignty." This is the right thing to do and can also demonstrate China's leadership.

Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban, the most pro-Russian leader among EU countries, said on Tuesday that he had asked Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to negotiate with Russia for a quick ceasefire. The Finnish president expressed disagreement.

"Russia only understands strength"

President Stubb said, "It is currently impossible to push for a ceasefire; real peace negotiations are needed." And "the only thing Russia understands is strength. Therefore, the more we can help Ukraine now, the sooner the war can end."

Stubb also urged Europe to strengthen its support for Ukraine while enhancing its own defense capabilities in traditional military fields and against Russia's hybrid warfare.

Stubb stated that Ukraine needs both material assistance (including financial aid) and political support, including paving the way for joining the EU and NATO.

He said Europe needs to transition to a "wartime economy," pooling ammunition and weapons orders to give the defense industry a long-term outlook. In addition to state funding, Stubb also called on the European Investment Bank, where he once served as vice president, to cross the red line and start being more "optimistic" about the development of the military industry.

Russia's hybrid warfare includes migration

Like most countries on NATO's eastern flank, Finland has experienced some types of Russia's hybrid warfare in recent months: cyberattacks, GPS interference, airspace violations, and using migration as a "military tool."

President Stubb said, "Russia is trying to make us overreact or respond unusually through hybrid attacks. However, attributing these hybrid attacks to Russia also helps to stop such attacks." "If you refuse to acknowledge reality or ignore it, then I think Russia will continue to do so."

Finland shares a border of over 1,300 kilometers (800 miles) with Russia, guarding half of NATO's border with its main adversary, and has a history of difficult coexistence with Russia.

As a grand duchy of the Russian Empire, Finland gained independence in 1917 after more than 100 years of Russian rule and fought two wars with the Soviet Union, ceding some territory in 1944. Finland then carefully navigated a period of neutrality during the Cold War (out of necessity, not choice), maintaining its independence while complying with Moscow under the so-called Finlandization policy.

Europe's strongest artillery

After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Finland followed Sweden in joining the EU, with both countries joining in 1995. However, before Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Finnish policymakers rarely viewed Russia as a major military threat, at least publicly. But in April 2023, Finland joined NATO.

To survive, this Nordic country has always remained vigilant against Russia. It can deploy 280,000 troops in wartime and has one of the most powerful artillery forces in Europe.

Stubb said, "Finland is currently one of the most important countries in Europe geopolitically and geostrategically because we have just doubled NATO's border with Russia." "Many people are counting on us."

On July 3rd, during an interview with American media, Zelensky responded to earlier reports that Trump is negotiating with Russian leader Putin about how much Ukrainian territory Moscow can retain.

In Trump's plan, the consideration to end the Russia-Ukraine war involves Ukraine giving up territory as a compromise.

In response, Zelensky told the media, "If Trump knows how to end this war, he should tell us today. If Ukraine's independence is at risk, if we are to lose our national status -- we want to be prepared, we want to know."

Zelensky warned that any proposal must avoid infringing on national sovereignty.

Clearly, Ukraine does not intend to give up its territory and sovereignty, and NATO is also transferring the command of aid to Ukraine from the United States to NATO leadership.

Trump may have considerable influence, but Europe will not give up, and Ukraine will not abandon its goals.

Earlier, Ukraine stated that even without aid, they would fight with shovels if necessary.

If Trump returns to the White House and forces Ukraine to give up territory for negotiations, it may not necessarily succeed.

**Russian Forces Destroy 5 Ukrainian Su-27s in a Single Strike, Sending a Warning to F-16s**

According to a report released by the Russian Ministry of Defense, Russian forces launched an "Iskander" tactical missile in a cluster attack on the Mirgorod airport in eastern Ukraine. The "Iskander" missile, equipped with a cluster warhead, penetrated the Ukrainian air defense network and struck five Su-27 fighter jets. Among them, two were completely destroyed, and three were damaged. This has left some netizens puzzled, wondering how Ukraine still has so many Su-27s after more than two years of conflict. Can Russian forces shoot down F-16s? Today, Lin will discuss whether the undefeated record of F-16s against Soviet and Russian aircraft might be broken.

After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Ukraine inherited approximately 77 Su-27 fighter jets. However, due to economic collapse and military corruption, by the time the Russia-Ukraine war began, only 32 of these jets were operational. Surprisingly, despite the war lasting over two years, these 32 jets have not been completely destroyed. What’s the reason behind this? In reality, Ukraine has very few Su-27s left, probably just over 10, as most have been shot down. The recent destruction of five Su-27s in a single strike is a significant blow to the Ukrainian Air Force.

The reason Ukraine still retains over 10 Su-27s is not due to the strength of its air force but because of its long-term strategy of keeping these jets in reserve. For instance, while Russian forces might deploy aircraft 30 times a day, Ukrainian forces might only deploy one or two sorties. Most of the time, Ukrainian Su-27s, MiG-29s, and Su-24s are kept in reserve, resulting in lower operational rates and fewer losses. After all, these aircraft represent the entirety of Ukraine’s air force; once they are gone, there are no replacements.

The timing of the Russian airstrike is also very strategic. The F-16 had just completed its first attack on the eastern Ukrainian battlefield. Although this attack was a probing one and did not cause significant damage to Russian forces, it marked the real deployment of the F-16 in the eastern Ukrainian theater. By attacking the Ukrainian airbase at this moment, Russian forces aimed to send a warning to the F-16s. Considering the underperformance of the Russian Aerospace Forces and air defense systems, many have doubted whether Russian forces can shoot down F-16s. Such doubts are entirely unnecessary.

The Russia-Ukraine war is the largest-scale conflict with the smallest technological gap between the two sides since the Cold War. As long as the F-16s enter eastern Ukraine, it is only a matter of time before they are shot down. Every weapon system incurs losses; the key is whether it can be replenished in time. As early as 2018, Houthi forces used old R-27 air-to-air missiles launched from the ground to accurately shoot down two Saudi F-15 fighter jets. The Saudi F-15s were custom versions with better performance than the U.S. military’s own, while the Ukrainian F-16s are early export versions. Without a technological gap, it is almost impossible for the F-16s to achieve zero losses in the eastern Ukrainian battlefield.

Moreover, the first batch of F-16s received by Ukraine is too small, only 4 to 6 aircraft. It is impossible to achieve air superiority with just 4 to 6 F-16s. Their primary function is to launch AIM-120 long-range air-to-air missiles to push back Russian Su-34 fighter-bombers.

The destruction of five Su-27s indicates that the Ukrainian forces are incapable of adequately protecting their airbases. To prevent the newly deployed F-16s from being destroyed immediately, Ukraine has applied to station them at neighboring countries' airbases, including Poland, the Czech Republic, and Slovakia.

Although the Russian S-300 and S-400 air defense systems have not performed as expected in combat, overhyping the F-16 will only lead to its quicker downfall from grace.

Focusing on battlefield dynamics and analyzing geopolitical disputes, welcome to the New Cold War Situation Room. I'm Yu Tong.

Today is July 3, 2024, marking the 861st day of the Russia-Ukraine war.

The Ukrainian General Staff released the latest data showing that in June 2024, the Russian army lost a total of 35,030 personnel in just one month. As of July 1, 2024, Russian battlefield losses have approached the 550,000 mark.

Notably, the elite 47th Brigade of the Ukrainian army is engaged in combat with two Russian brigades and five regiments in the Pokrovsk direction, eliminating 975 Russian soldiers in half a month. In the fierce battles on the northern flank of Avdiivka lasting eight months, the 47th Brigade has at least three times completely destroyed the combat capabilities of the Russian 15th and 30th Brigades.

The Ukrainian army pointed out that Russian soldiers are unwilling to be captured; they often use light weapons or grenades to blow themselves up or have their comrades end their lives.

Increasing evidence suggests that Russian soldiers are nearly depleted. Recruitment billboards have now appeared in major Russian cities like St. Petersburg and Novosibirsk. To attract new recruits, the authorities have raised the compensation for new soldiers to 1.3 million rubles, a 650% increase from 200,000 rubles two years ago. Additionally, these cities now frequently see funeral processions and retired personnel with prosthetics, a situation that was previously uncommon.

**Russia's Most Advanced Artillery Destroyed; Ukrainian Drones Achieve New Successes**

Currently, the Russian army mainly launches attacks in groups of infantry, with artillery continuously bombarding. Recently, there has been little activity from armored columns, but it is expected that the Russian army may soon regroup a large number of armored units for an offensive.

In the village of Stepove in Avdiivka, the Ukrainian 109th Brigade discovered a newly arrived Russian 2S19 self-propelled howitzer at a firing position, which was quickly destroyed by Ukrainian drones and FPV.

It is reported that the Russian army has gathered its remaining most advanced equipment in the Pokrovsk direction, but progress has been minimal.

Recently, a Roniny drone from the Ukrainian 56th Independent Mechanized Brigade hit a Russian fuel train near Tokmak in the Zaporizhzhia region.

It is unclear what damage was caused after the drone hit the 2TE116 diesel locomotive, as the drone could no longer transmit images after the explosion. "Defense Express" pointed out that this attack occurred within 20-30 kilometers of the front line, indicating that Ukrainian drone technology has improved. Additionally, the appearance of the fuel train suggests that the Russian army is actively developing a "railway corridor" from Donbas to Crimea, which will undoubtedly become a key target for Ukrainian FPV drones.

On the other hand, Russian attacks continue. On July 1, with the assistance of Russian drones, the Russian army used Iskander missiles to attack the Ukrainian Myrhorod Air Base. A Russian blogger claimed that at least three F-16s were destroyed.

Ukrainian Air Force official Yury Ignat admitted that the Myrhorod Air Base was hit by missiles. Satellite images show that the Russian army destroyed at least one Su-27 aircraft, with several other aircraft damaged, but there were no F-16s at this base.

Some analysts believe that the Ukrainian army's placement of unprotected Su-27 fighters within the range of Iskander missiles is more of a strategy to confuse the Russian army, possibly aiming to deplete Russian missiles. If these planes were operational, they should be fully fueled and ready to take off. However, reports suggest that these planes might be non-flying Su-27 spare parts that have been parked at the airport for a long time, lacking any camouflage or air defense measures.

Regarding the F-16, Russian media have reported that Ukrainian F-16 fighters were detected over Kherson, accompanied by NATO AWACS, but there was no engagement.

Dutch Defense Minister Kajsa Ollongren recently stated that two F-16 fighters will be sent to Ukraine. They can be used anywhere, including within Russian territory. It seems the F-16 will soon make its official debut.

**Russian Troops Terrified; Urgently Arming Crimea**

On July 1, Ukrainian missiles struck Sevastopol in Crimea. The Russian army claimed to have shot down all the missiles, but their logistics base was suspected to have been hit, with losses still being clarified.

The repeatedly attacked Russian army is now like a "frightened bird." On July 1, they installed a Tor M2KM surface-to-air missile system near the Sevastopol beach.

This move significantly endangers local civilians' safety because the surface-to-air missile system itself is a high-value military target, likely to attract enemy attacks. In emergencies, the missile system might mistakenly identify and attack non-military targets, causing unintended harm to nearby residents and infrastructure. Additionally, radiation and explosion hazards may also arise.

Furthermore, Russia has turned Crimea into a heavily guarded area, setting up over 233 military bases and using civilians as human shields. Despite the militarization, Russia still encourages tourism, putting civilians at risk and violating international law.

A few days ago, a missile hit a seaside resort in Crimea, causing hundreds of casualties. Ukraine then paused its attacks on Crimea for a few days. Ukrainian military expert Roman Svitan stated in an interview that this pause gave the Russians a chance to regroup, disperse air defense systems, and move them to new locations.

Svitan believes that the Ukrainian army should have no reservations and must maintain high-intensity strikes to destroy the Russian air defense systems on the island, ideally striking daily. The Russian army needs 1.5 to 2 days to move air defense systems from one place to another, and continuous strikes can weaken their ability to mobilize air defense systems to protect themselves.

Observers believe that once Crimea's air defense systems are exhausted, Ukrainian F-16s and even landing forces could strike Crimea.

**Aerial Bombs Strike Russian Forces; Motorcycle Charges Appear on the Frontline**

In the Kharkiv region, the Ukrainian army used precision bombs, various artillery, and drones to fiercely attack the Russian army, forcing them to redeploy troops for reinforcement. The Ukrainian army has sent tens of thousands of soldiers to Kharkiv, significantly outnumbering the Russian forces, but has not launched a major offensive. Analysts believe that the Ukrainian army aims to achieve its goals through continuous attrition of Russian forces. The Kharkiv battle will become a burden for the Russian army.

Reports indicate that a Russian assault team entered the Sumy region of Ukraine, attempting to create a new hotspot, but their assembly point was directly destroyed by a Ukrainian JDAM bomb. Provoking in Sumy will not yield good results.

In the Kherson region, the Ukrainian army used missiles to attack a Russian base on the left bank of Nova Kakhovka, causing several explosions and a subsequent fire. The extent of the damage is still unclear.

In the Bakhmut war zone, Ukrainian Air Force aircraft used precision AASM-250 "Hammer" aerial bombs to bomb a Russian gathering point in the northern suburb of Paraskoviivka, achieving significant results.

However, Ukrainian forces stationed in high-rise buildings are currently suffering heavy bombardment from Russian TOS-2. The TOS-2 uses 220mm rockets filled with highly flammable triethylaluminum. This agent can ignite in the air and explode upon contact with water. It is highly corrosive to human skin and can continue to burn even when buried in the ground, likely causing significant Ukrainian casualties.

Nazar Voloshyn, spokesperson for the Ukrainian Khortytsia Island Joint Task Force, stated in a live TV broadcast on July 1 that the Russian army is now fiercely attacking in the Horlivka-Toretsk direction, with the offensive on Chasiv Yar weakening.

Voloshyn pointed out that Russia's attack on Toretsk aims to exert pressure on Chasiv Yar from another direction.

Some analysts believe that the Russian attack on Toretsk is due to heavy casualties in Chasiv Yar, leading to war-weariness among soldiers, prompting them to continue the attrition war in a different location.

Observers have also noted that to avoid Ukrainian drone attacks, the Russian army has started using motorcycles to transport ammunition to the front line and has launched motorcycle charges. On July 1, the Ukrainian 72nd Brigade destroyed a Russian motorcycle charge attack in Vuhledar. This may indicate the worsening equipment situation of the Russian army.

The "Southern Daily" used AI models to examine satellite images of 87 Russian military bases, including 16 bases storing tanks, artillery, and armored personnel carriers. The results show a significant reduction in the number of Russian armored vehicles since February 24, 2022.

The "New York Times" reported that the new tactic of motorcycle charges is spreading on the front line, adding more chaos and brutality to the battle. The Russian army is trying to use the speed advantage of motorcycles to cross open ground, adapting to a battlefield filled with mines and drones. Although this tactic is extremely risky, it addresses the key challenge of crossing open ground under drone and artillery surveillance.

Sergeant Sapsan of the Ukrainian 47th Mechanized Brigade stated, "They get close and then dismount to start shooting... These off-road vehicles and motorcycles are very fast." Although this tactic has led to significant Russian casualties, it has indeed achieved some success in breaking through drone and artillery blockades.

Therefore, there is concern about when he might abandon the 75-year-old North Atlantic Treaty Alliance if re-elected. However, interviews with former Trump national security officials and defense experts who might serve in Trump's second term suggest that Trump is unlikely to completely withdraw from NATO but will continue to demand that European member countries significantly increase their military spending.

In an interview, defense expert Dan Caldwell, familiar with the internal thoughts of Trump's national security advisor circle, said, "We really have no choice." He cited the rising U.S. national debt, recruitment difficulties in the military, and the weak foundation of the U.S. defense industry as challenges in facing Moscow and Beijing.

Trump and his presidential campaign team have not yet appointed a new national security team or publicly accepted a new agenda for NATO. However, discussions on related issues are ongoing within Trump's campaign team. Former officials and experts interviewed stated that if Trump wins, in his second term, the U.S. will retain its air forces and bases in Germany, the UK, and Turkey, as well as naval forces, to maintain the nuclear umbrella over Europe. Meanwhile, most infantry, armor, logistics, and artillery will eventually be handed over to European countries.

Caldwell stated that this shift would involve "a significant and substantial reduction in the U.S.'s security role, not being the primary provider of combat power in Europe, but providing support only in times of crisis."

Another part of Trump's plan is a two-tier NATO system. This idea was first proposed by another former senior Trump administration official, retired Army Lieutenant General Keith Kellogg. It means that NATO member countries that have not met the goal of spending 2% of their GDP on defense budgets will not receive U.S. defense security guarantees.

Although Article 5 of NATO stipulates that an attack on any member country is considered an attack on all member countries, requiring an immediate response from other members, Trump's foreign policy think tank members claim that the wording of Article 5 is flexible and does not require any member country to respond with military force.

To date, the U.S. is the largest contributor to the military alliance NATO, with a defense budget of about $860 billion, accounting for 68% of NATO's total defense budget in 2023. Jeremy Shapiro, research director at the pan-European think tank "The European Council on Foreign Relations" (ECFR), stated that a significant portion of the U.S. defense budget (about 3.5% of U.S. GDP) is used to defend Europe, although the Pentagon refuses to disclose specific amounts.

Kiron Skinner, former director of the U.S. State Department's Policy Planning Office during the Trump administration and a key figure in "Project 2025," said, "The U.S. is not the world's ATM. NATO can play an important role in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific theaters, but we need more strategic thinking."

Trump's new NATO policy plan could also play a key role in quickly resolving the ongoing 2.5-year Russia-Ukraine war, which he believes "should never have started." The Republican presidential candidate is considering reaching an agreement with Russian President Putin to decide which countries can join NATO, particularly Ukraine and Georgia. This would have a significant impact on NATO's vague commitment to Ukraine's future, a commitment the Biden administration is implementing without a timeline.

According to a national security expert familiar with Trump's thinking, who wished to remain anonymous, Trump "is open to stopping NATO expansion and will not return to Ukraine's 1991 borders. This will be on the table. But this does not mean abandoning any other possibilities, including providing substantial weapons to Ukraine."

The report stated that NATO is planning new measures to protect support for Ukraine. This plan has been underway for months and is accelerating due to Biden's poor performance in the first U.S. presidential debate. NATO's measures include sending a new senior civilian official to Kyiv and establishing a new military command in Wiesbaden, western Germany, to coordinate military aid and training for Ukrainian forces from NATO member countries.

The new military command in Wiesbaden is called "NATO Security Assistance and Training for Ukraine," consisting of about 700 U.S. and allied personnel from all NATO member countries.

Trump has barely concealed his disappointment with NATO allies, repeatedly criticizing them for taking advantage of U.S. security assistance in Europe and failing to meet the NATO defense budget commitment (2% of GDP). In 2014, NATO member countries agreed to spend 2% of their GDP on defense budgets, but many countries have failed to meet this goal.

Reuters reported that in recent years, NATO allies' defense budgets have been highly controversial, especially with former U.S. President Trump criticizing European allies for spending too little on their own security and relying on U.S. protection. Earlier this year, Trump hinted that he would not protect NATO allies whose defense budgets are less than 2% of GDP.

On June 17, NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg, during a meeting with U.S. President Biden at the White House, said that five years ago, fewer than ten NATO allies met the goal of spending at least 2% of GDP on defense budgets. He emphasized how NATO allies have increased their continuous military spending since Russia seized Crimea from Ukraine in 2014.

Stoltenberg said, "In Europe and Canada, NATO allies' defense budgets have increased by 18% this year, the largest increase in decades. Twenty-three allies will spend 2% or more of their GDP on defense this year."

NATO Secretary-General Stoltenberg stated that when NATO leaders set the goal of spending 2% of GDP on defense budgets at the 2014 summit, only three allies, the U.S., Greece, and the UK, met this goal. At that time, NATO had 28 member countries, now it has increased to 32.

Earlier, Stoltenberg said at a speech at the Wilson Center think tank that increasing defense spending by NATO allies "benefits both Europe and the U.S., especially since most of this additional funding is spent in the U.S."

NATO Negotiates Nuclear Weapons Deployment

The UK's The Daily Telegraph reported in June that NATO Secretary-General Stoltenberg, in an interview with the media, said that facing the increasing threats from Moscow and Beijing, NATO is negotiating the deployment of more nuclear weapons and keeping them on standby.

Stoltenberg said, "I will not discuss in detail how many nuclear warheads should be available and which nuclear warheads should be stored, but we need to consult on these nuclear weapons issues. This is what we are doing. Transparency helps convey a direct message: we (NATO) are a nuclear alliance." "NATO's goal is, of course, a world without nuclear weapons, but as long as nuclear weapons exist, we will continue to be a nuclear alliance because Russia, China, and North Korea have nuclear weapons. If NATO did not have nuclear weapons, the world would be a more dangerous place."

Previously, Stoltenberg stated that nuclear weapons are NATO's "ultimate security guarantee" and a way to maintain peace, serving as a deterrent.

NATO has played a greater role in coordinating weapons aid to Kyiv but rarely talks publicly about nuclear weapons, although the U.S. has deployed nuclear weapons at multiple locations in Europe. According to the Federation of American Scientists, Russia and the U.S. are by far the world's largest nuclear powers, possessing about 88% of the world's nuclear weapons.

According to the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the U.S. has deployed about 100 non-strategic B61 nuclear weapons in five European countries: Italy, Germany, Turkey, Belgium, and the Netherlands. There are another 100 such nuclear weapons within the U.S.

Russia has about 1,558 non-strategic nuclear warheads. However, arms control experts say it is difficult to estimate how many nuclear warheads Russia actually has, as it is a military secret.

In the Zaporizhzhia region, on the 29th, an Iskander-M missile hit a Ukrainian convoy 50 kilometers from the front line, causing significant losses. Russian sources claim they destroyed Ukrainian M113s, BUK-M1s, BMP-1s, and trucks. It is unclear what system the Russian military used for the attack.

On the Avdiivka front, Russia nearly controls the entire Sokil and continues to advance along the Novoleksandrivka-Sokil-Umansk line, trying to level the front line, but progress is slower than earlier this year.

On June 30, Ukraine released data showing continued high Russian personnel and equipment losses, though the intensity has decreased compared to previous periods.

In the past six months, due to a lack of air defense missiles, Ukrainians have resorted to various methods to defend their skies, including using and improving 40-year-old propeller planes like the Yak-52, which recently had some success.

On June 29, a Yak-52 reportedly confronted a Russian reconnaissance drone in the air and shot it down at close range with a shotgun. Although propeller planes are slower than jets, they are faster than drones, allowing the Yak-52 to catch up with the Russian Zala drone.

**F-16s May Have Seen First Combat in Ukraine: When Will Full Air Superiority Be Achieved?**

On June 29, former Ukrainian Air Force pilot and air defense advisor Xavier Taitman announced on social media that the first batch of F-16 fighter jets had arrived in Ukraine and conducted their first attack, confirmed by the International Legion.

Danish Royal Air Force Commander Major General Jan Dam recently stated that the plan to deliver F-16 fighter jets to Ukraine is expected to be completed on schedule. However, he emphasized that for operational security reasons, specific dates could not be disclosed but hoped to deliver as planned. When the fighter jets are ready in Ukraine, everyone will be informed.

Previously, Denmark, Belgium, Norway, and the Netherlands had stated they would deliver F-16s to Ukraine in June or summer. Given the recent destruction of Russian air defense systems in Crimea, including the S-500 system, and frequent bombings in Russia's Belgorod region using U.S.-made precision-guided bombs, there is reason to believe that F-16s may already be in combat.

Of course, the initial batch of F-16s received by Ukraine will not be large, estimated at 4 to 6 aircraft, related to Ukraine's logistical maintenance capabilities.

Since this war is essentially a confrontation between the entire West and Russia, although Russian weapons are not as powerful as their published data suggests, the presence of nuclear weapons has led the West to set self-imposed red lines in aiding Ukraine. Therefore, the number of F-16s provided by the West is indeed limited, only gradually improving Ukraine's air defense capabilities.

Many imagine that the arrival of F-16s will immediately change the battlefield situation, but this may not happen because the initial number of F-16s received by Ukraine is insufficient to form an overwhelming military advantage.

Major General Jan Dam also stated that even if Ukraine receives F-16 fighter jets, it will still be unable to fully control its airspace. He pointed out: "Ukraine has a lot of work to do to gain air superiority. They need more effective air and ground air defense forces."

In other words, while F-16s can help Ukraine gain partial air superiority and intercept Russian missiles and drones, Ukraine still needs to further eliminate Russian air defense systems and use Patriot systems to protect F-16 bases. Currently, Ukraine is using HIMARS to launch ATACMS missiles for such tasks.

It is estimated that after receiving the F-16s, Ukraine will first try to clear front-line and Crimean air defense systems by launching precision glide bombs from a distance and using air-to-air missiles to intercept Russian missiles.

Additionally, the limited number of pilots and slow training progress are challenges Ukraine faces. The shortage of ground crew is also a problem, though less known. In fact, training experienced ground crew takes much longer than training pilots. However, it is possible that the West may provide corresponding support services to fill this gap.

Some analysts believe that the first pilots flying Ukraine's F-16s may not be Ukrainian pilots trained by the West but rather F-16 pilots from the International Legion. Previously, many former U.S. F-16 pilots expressed their willingness to fly F-16s for Ukraine in combat.

Regarding the defensive capabilities of the F-16, Major General Jan Dam stated: "If an F-16 is shot down, it would be a significant strategic victory for Russia. We are doing our best to ensure Ukrainian pilots are proficient in operating the F-16 to minimize risks. But I can't guarantee anything. Of course, if some are shot down, I would be very sorry."

Indeed, any weapon on the battlefield, including the F-35, is at risk of being shot down, let alone the F-16. Currently, Ukraine can only reduce the risk of F-16s being shot down through preliminary work.

More importantly, the F-16 is just a combat platform, and its power depends on the weapon configuration provided by the Biden administration for Ukraine's F-16s. Additionally, for the F-16 to truly exert significant power, it needs the Swedish-provided early warning aircraft to be in place.

While the F-16 is not omnipotent, it plays a crucial role in the development of the situation. The F-16, combined with the Patriot air defense system, will effectively change the situation of Russian forces dropping FAB bombs. If confirmed that F-16s participated in the first combat, it will further deepen the impression that the current situation favors Ukraine.

**More Senior Russian Officials Wanted: Israel to Aid with 8 Patriot Systems**

Latest reports indicate that the Financial Times cited sources saying the U.S., Israel, and Ukraine are discussing Israel's plan to provide up to 8 Patriot air defense systems to Ukraine to help it resist Russian attacks. This aid requires support from the Biden administration or equivalent military aid to Israel in exchange.

These M901 PAC-2 systems, deployed during the Gulf War, are older than the Patriot PAC-3 systems currently used by Ukraine. However, the PAC-2's advantage lies in its longer range, similar to how Ukraine's S-200 compares to the S-300, posing a greater threat to Russian Su-34s launching glide bombs. Most importantly, these Patriots can launch the intercept missiles currently provided by the U.S. to Ukraine.

Russia's troubles don't end there. Last week, the International Criminal Court in The Hague issued arrest warrants for former Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and Russian Army Chief of Staff Valery Gerasimov, accusing them of war crimes and crimes against humanity during the invasion of Ukraine. These senior officials are accused of participating in multiple crimes, including bombing Ukraine's civilian energy infrastructure. This move marks further legal accountability by the International Criminal Court for senior Russian officials, including other key figures leading the invasion alongside Russian President Putin. Although Russia is not a member of the International Criminal Court, these charges could have significant international repercussions, including travel restrictions and other sanctions against the accused.
